facts.text: Kundan Sugar Mills is a partnership concern owning a sugar mill at Amroha.

facts.text: In 1951 the partners of the appellant-Mills purchased the building machinery and other equipment of another sugar mill at Kiccha in Nainital district.

anchor.surface_text: In 1951 the partners of the appellant-Mills purchased the building machinery and other equipment of another sugar mill at Kiccha in the district of Nainital.

facts.text: Partners closed the mill at Kiccha and started it at Bulandshahr named Pannijee Sugar General Mills.

anchor.surface_text: They closed the said mill at Kiccha and started it at Bulandshahr. The new factory was named Pannijee Sugar General Mills, Bulandshahr.

facts.text: On January 19, 1955, General Manager of appellant-Mills ordered transfer of respondents 1 to 4 to the new mill at Bulandshahr.

facts.text: Respondents 1 to 4 through fifth respondent protested the transfer to General Manager.

anchor.surface_text: Bulandshahr. The said respondents through their representative, the fifth respondent, protested to the General Manager against the said transfer.

facts.text: General Manager by letter dated January 22/24, 1955 insisted on respondents joining the new mill at Bulandshahr.

anchor.surface_text: But the General Manager, by his letter dated January 22/24, 1955, insisted upon their joining the new mill at Bulandshabr.

facts.text: Respondents 1 to 4 did not join the new mill.

anchor.surface_text: But the said respondents did number accede to his request.

facts.text: On January 28, 1955, General Manager served notice on respondents 1 to 4 for disobeying orders and committing misconduct under Standing Order No. 1a.

facts.text: Labour Union by letter dated January 31, 1955 denied the charges.

facts.text: On February 2, 1955, General Manager dismissed respondents 1 to 4 for disobeying transfer order, guilty of misconduct under Standing Order No. 1a.

facts.text: Government of U.P. by notification dated November 7, 1955 referred the dispute to State Industrial Tribunal at Allahabad.

holdings.text: It was not a condition of service of employment of the respondents either express or implied that the employer has the right to transfer them to a new concern started by him subsequent to the date of their employment.
holdings.reasoning_summary: No express term conceded; cannot imply term as new concern started after employment not in contemplation of parties; two mills distinct entities with different conditions, places, accounts; distinguishes precedents involving single unit/concern.

holdings.text: The two mills at Amroha and Bulandshahr are treated as two different entities.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear that the two mills are situated at different places with accounts separately maintained and governed by different service conditions, though they happened to be under the common management therefore, they are treated as two different entities.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Different locations, separate accounts, different service conditions including benefits, bonuses, despite common ownership and management.

holdings.text: The Government Order No. 6122/ST/XXXVI-A-640/S-T-1953 has no relevancy to the question raised; it does not prevent transfer if contractual right exists, but no such right here.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Order requires re-employment in same factory for seasonal workers but does not prohibit transfer where contract permits; employer lacks contractual right to transfer.

holdings.text: A substantial question of law arose regarding employer's right to transfer between concerns, conferring jurisdiction on Labour Appellate Tribunal under s.7(1) Industrial Disputes Appellate Tribunal Act, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold that a substantial question of law arose in the case and that it was well within the powers of the Labour Appellate Tribunal to entertain the appeal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Whether employer has right to transfer from one concern to another is substantial question of law.

precedents.citation: Alexandre Bouzourou v. The Ottoman Bank  1 ... A.T.R. 1930 P.C. 118, 119.

anchor.surface_text: In Alexandre Bouzourou v. The Ottoman Bank  1  the appellant was an employee of the respondent-bank. The bank transferred him from one branch to another branch of the bank situated in different towns. As he refused to companyply with the order of transfer, he was dismissed. Thereafter, he filed a suit to recover damages from the bank for wrongful dismissal. It was argued before the Judicial Committee that under the terms of his companytract of service the sphere of his employment included only the head office and number the branches of the bank. The evidence in that case showed that transfer was one of the ordinary incidents of the banks employment, being usually companycurrent with an A.T.R. 1930 P.C. 118, 119.

precedents.case_name: Alexandre Bouzourou v. The Ottoman Bank
precedents.cited_proposition: Transfer between branches of the same bank is an ordinary incident of service, implying a term in the contract allowing such transfers.
precedents.cited_holding: From the point of view of proper organization of their staff it is difficult to assume that the Bank would willingly agree that their employees should number be bound to serve outside the place where the companytract was made except with their companysent, and, in their Lordships opinion such a companydition of the companytract would require to be clearly established.

precedents.citation: Mary Anamalai Plantation Workers Union v. Seliparai estate  2 ... 1956 I.L.L.J. 343.

anchor.surface_text: In Mary  Anamalai Plantation Workers Union  v. Seliparai estate  2 , labour was recruited in the plantations without any differentiation being made between factory and field workers and it had been the companymon practice prevailing for several years to transfer the factory workers to the field and vice-versa, according to the exigencies of work. A worker who had been appointed in such a plantation was transferred, owing to mechanisation in the factory, from the factory to the field. The Labour Appellate Tribunal of India held that in the circumstances of the case the liability to be so transferred must be deemed to be an implied companydition of service.

precedents.case_name: Mary Anamalai Plantation Workers Union v. Seliparai Estate
precedents.cited_proposition: In plantations where labour is recruited without distinction between factory and field workers and common practice of mutual transfers exists, liability to transfer is an implied condition of service.

precedents.citation: Bata Shoe Company, Ltd. v. Ali Hasan Industrial Tribunal, Patna Ors.  3 ... 1956 1 L.L.J. 278.

anchor.surface_text: So too in Bata Shoe Company, Ltd. v. Ali Hasan  Industrial Tribunal, Patna Ors.   3  transfer of an employee in the circumstances of that, case from one post to another was held number to be an alteration of any service companydition within the meaning of s. 33 of the Industrial Disputes Act. That was a case of a management employing a worker in one companycern and transferring him from one post to another.

precedents.case_name: Bata Shoe Company Ltd. v. Ali Hasan Industrial Tribunal Patna Ors.
precedents.cited_proposition: Transfer of employee from one post to another within the same concern does not constitute alteration of service conditions under s. 33 Industrial Disputes Act.

precedents.citation: S. N. Mukherjee v. Kemp Co. Ltd.  4 ... 1954 L.A.C. 903

anchor.surface_text: S. N. Mukherjee v. Kemp Co. Ltd.  4  was a case arising out of s. 23 of the Industrial Disputes Appellate Tribunal Act, 1950. The companyplaint there was that an employee was transferred by the management with a view to victimize him and that it amounted to alteration in the companyditions of employment. It was held that if an employer employed a person it was implicit in the appointment that he companyld be transferred to any place where the business of the employer in the same line was situated, unless there was an express companydition to the companytrary in the companytract of employment.

precedents.case_name: S. N. Mukherjee v. Kemp Co. Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: It is implicit in the contract of employment that an employee can be transferred to any place where the employer's business in the same line is situated, absent express contrary term.
